content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata> <idinfo> <citation> <citeinfo> <origin>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</origin> <pubdate>20120829</pubdate> <title>Threatened Eider Geodatabase, Spectacled and Steller's Eider Observations. Arctic LCC (2012)</title> <edition>2012</edition> <geoform>vector digital data</geoform> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Fairbanks, AK</pubplace> <publish>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</publish> </pubinfo> <othercit>Users are strongly encouraged to cite original data sources whenever they extract information from the larger dataset for specific analysis.</othercit> <onlink>http://arcticlcc.org/products/</onlink> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract>This point feature class represents observations of threatened eiders [Spectacled (Somateria fischeri) and Steller's (Polysticta stelleri)] and is one component of the Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperatives (Arctic LCC) Threatened Eider Geodatabase.  This database is intended to be a qualitative "first look" at where these two species of eider have been recorded and where surveys have been conducted. This spatial dataset is intended for general planning and mapping purposes rather than for deriving density estimates. The geodatabase is comprised of two feature classes (SPEI_STEI_Observations and Survey_Polys) and two tables (Eider_Incidental_attributes and Eider_Reference_Information).</abstract> <purpose>The Arctic LCC created the Threatened Eider Geodatabase to serve as a primary repository for threatened eider distribution information.  This database is intended to be a qualitative "first look" at where these two species of eider have been recorded and where surveys have been conducted.  This dataset is intended for general planning and mapping purposes, it should NOT be used for deriving density estimates.  Users are reminded that these data do not represent all locations within the geographic scope of this database that may be occupied by threatened eiders.</purpose> <supplinf> Observations of eiders are considered to have been derived from a survey if both of the following conditions are met 1) there was a search area with reasonably well-defined boundaries, and 2) eiders were among the taxa specifically targeted by the survey.  All observations of eiders that do not meet these criteria are treated as incidental observations - these could include observations contributed by persons engaged in activities other than wildlife surveys, observations obtained during the course of biological survey work targeted at another species such as caribou, and historical observations from the literature.  Observations associated with surveys are related to the Survey_Polys feature class via the SURVEY_ID field that uniquely identifies each survey.   A survey is defined as a defined geographic area under observation for a discrete time period.  For example, an area surveyed annually will have a separate record for each survey-year.  Within-year replicates are also listed as separate surveys unless the data are summarized by year.  Incidental observations are assigned the non-unique value Incidental  in the SURVEY_ID field and are related to the Eider_Incidental_Attributes table via a unique value in the Incd_ID field.  We have focused our effort on importing and standardizing the GIS data. In some cases, these data do not necessarily agree with the numbers cited in the corresponding reports, often due to the treatment of On/Off transect or Flying/Not Flying observations. Proofing comments are provided in the Comments field. In most cases, only the authors of the reports will be able to identify the reasons for the discrepancies. Please refer to individual reports referenced in the Eider_References_Information table via the Ref_ID.  This database should NOT be used to estimate densities. It is a qualitative "first look" at where surveys have been conducted and where eiders have been recorded, rather than an uniformly rigorous quantification of survey effort. While some survey polygons are very accurate, others are generalized and noted as such.   Not all survey polygons have associated observations. This is because some polygons are associated with null results (i.e., no eiders seen on the survey). The inclusion of null survey polygons is incomplete at this stage. In the interests of time, only polygons for null surveys that were readily available were included. Specifically, null survey polygons are incomplete for some sites and years for Spectacled and Steller's Eider surveys at remote Air Force sites in Alaska. </supplinf> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <rngdates> <begdate>1991</begdate> <enddate>2010</enddate> </rngdates> </timeinfo> <current>ground condition</current> </timeperd> <status> <progress>Complete</progress> <update>As needed</update> </status> <spdom> <bounding> <westbc>-169.0</westbc> <eastbc>-135.0</eastbc> <northbc>74.7</northbc> <southbc>66.5</southbc> </bounding> </spdom> <keywords> <theme> <themekt>ISO 19115 Topic Category</themekt> <themekey>biota</themekey> </theme> <theme> <themekt>User</themekt> <themekey>eiders</themekey> <themekey>spectacled eiders</themekey> <themekey>Steller's eiders</themekey> <themekey>eider observations</themekey> </theme> <place> <placekt>None</placekt> <placekey>Alaska</placekey> </place> </keywords> <accconst>None.</accconst> <useconst>Neither the Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative or contributors to this dataset shall be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.  In an effort to provide the most comprehensive overview possible, we have incorporated many data sources, representing many different survey methods. It is not possible to apply a uniform quantification of survey effort across this wide variety of data sets because not all of the eider observations are associated with a clearly defined survey area. Therefore, the user should NOT aggregating data from multiple sources to derive density estimates. When interpreting these data, users are reminded to consider that detectability of eiders is a function of many variables, including differences in species, habitat, time-of-year, weather conditions, and survey techniques. Inherent in any data set used to develop graphical representations, are limitations of accuracy as determined by, among others, the source, scale and resolution of the data.</useconst> <ptcontac> <cntinfo> <cntorgp> <cntorg>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</cntorg> </cntorgp> <cntpos>Geospatial Specialist</cntpos> <cntaddr> <addrtype>mailing and physical address</addrtype> <address>101 12th Ave, Room 110</address> <city>Fairbanks</city> <state>Alaska</state> <postal>99701</postal> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>907 456 0327</cntvoice> <cntemail>data@arcticlcc.org</cntemail> <cntinst>Contact by phone or email.</cntinst> </cntinfo> </ptcontac> <datacred>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</datacred> <secinfo> <secsys>FIPS Pub 199</secsys> <secclass>No Confidentiality</secclass> <sechandl>Standard Technical Controls</sechandl> </secinfo> <native>Microsoft Windows 7; ESRI ArcGIS 10</native> </idinfo> <dataqual> <logic>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative (Arctic LCC) staff and contractors have compiled this dataset to the best of their abilities using the resources available to them.  Although the data have been gathered by sources believed to be reliable, Arctic LCC neither verifies nor guarantees the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of these data.  If you find any errors or omissions, we encourage you to report them to the Arctic LCC data custodian (data@arcticlcc.org).</logic> <complete>Users are reminded that these data do not represent all locations within the geographic scope of this database that may be occupied by threatened eiders.</complete> <lineage> <procstep> <procdesc>Data were collected from different sources and subsequently processed (reformatted) so that they could be aggregated and distributed.</procdesc> <procdate>20100401</procdate> </procstep> </lineage> </dataqual> <spdoinfo> <direct>Point</direct> <ptvctinf> <sdtsterm> <sdtstype>Point</sdtstype> </sdtsterm> </ptvctinf> </spdoinfo> <spref> <horizsys> <planar> <mapproj> <mapprojn>Albers Conical Equal Area</mapprojn> <albers> <stdparll>55</stdparll> <stdparll>65</stdparll> <longcm>-154</longcm> <latprjo>50</latprjo> <feast>0</feast> <fnorth>0</fnorth> </albers> </mapproj> <planci> <plance>coordinate pair</plance> <coordrep> <absres>0.002048</absres> <ordres>0.002048</ordres> </coordrep> <plandu>meters</plandu> </planci> </planar> <geodetic> <horizdn>North American Datum of 1983</horizdn> <ellips>Geodetic Reference System 80</ellips> <semiaxis>6378137</semiaxis> <denflat>298.25722</denflat> </geodetic> </horizsys> </spref> <eainfo> <detailed> <enttyp> <enttypl>SPEI_STEI_Observations</enttypl> <enttypd>This feature class represents observations of threatened eiders.</enttypd> <enttypds>Arctic LCC</enttypds> </enttyp> <attr> <attrlabl>OBJECTID</attrlabl> <attrdef>Internal feature number.</attrdef> <attrdefs>ESRI</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <udom>Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.</udom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Shape</attrlabl> <attrdef>Feature geometry.</attrdef> <attrdefs>ESRI</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <udom>Coordinates defining the features.</udom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Observ_ID</attrlabl> <attrdef>Required.  Unique identifier for each observation.   This field serves as the primary key for the Observation attributes table.  The 'OBSERV_ID' will be a combination of contributor (limited to a maximum of 6 characters)underscore year (YYYY) underscore observation # (sequential).  Examples:  ABR_2005_001, ABR_2005_002, and FWS_2005_001.</attrdef> <attrdefs>Arctic LCC</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <udom>Free text</udom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Incd_ID</attrlabl> <attrdef>Required.  Unique identifier for incidental observations.  Any observation that occurs outside of surveys that targeted eiders will be assigned an incidental ID (Incd_ID).  The 'Incd_ID' will be a combination of 'Incd' underscore year (YYYY) underscore incidental # (sequential).  Examples:  Incd_2004_999, Incd_2005_001, and Incd_2005_002.  In addition to being assigned an 'Incd_ID', incidental observations will also be assigned the non-unique value 'Incidental' in the 'SURVEY_ID' field.</attrdef> <attrdefs>Arctic LCC</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <udom>Free text</udom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Survey_ID</attrlabl> <attrdef>Required.   Unique identifier for each survey.  A survey will be assigned a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdSURVEY_ID\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd only if eiders are one of the targeted species or survey methods are such that there is a reasonable probability that the presence of eiders would be detected.  The \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdSURVEY_ID\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd will be a combination of contributor (limited to a maximum of 6 characters) underscore year (YYYY) underscore purpose code (PN, NE, BR, BP, MO; see \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdPurpose\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd for code definitions) underscore survey # (sequential).  Examples:  ABR_2005_BP_001, ABR_2005_BP_002, and FWS_2005_PN_001.</attrdef> <attrdefs>Arctic LCC</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <udom>Free text</udom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Species</attrlabl> <attrdef>Required.
